text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonymous questions. 

Career stage: junior (1-3 years of experience)

"I'm a marketer with ~3 years of experience. I've been working as the solo marketer at a startup for a year now. My background is in content, but obviously as the marketing team of one, I've been doing a little bit of everything. Our team is growing and I've discussed my desire to do more with content and level up my content career with our CEO (who I report to). With annual reviews coming up, I'm certain that I need to come up with some goals for the next year (and my career in general). I do everything right now — SEO, thought leadership, general website stuff, social, and a bunch of other non-content stuff. 

It feels embarrassing to ask but... I don't know what my goals should be. I want to continue to learn, I want to possibly help new/aspiring content marketers get a taste of the content world, and I want to take on new responsibilities so I can grow... but I don't really know what actual goals should be. If you were advising a junior-ish marketer on how to grow in their career, what would you recommend? How do you start the "next phase" of a content career? Thank you for any advice. 
"
I’m also not a growth guy, and would love to be a fly on the wall of this one. My distribution game can use all the tips I can get!

elements.text: I’m also not a growth guy, and would love to be a fly on the wall of this one. My distribution game can use all the tips I can get!

text:
One of the most important ways you can level up your career is by gaining a better understanding of business metrics and how your content efforts tie into them. this is the biggest gap I've seen in my experience as a marketing consultant — wayyyyy too many marketing teams, especially on the content side, don't really get why certain tactics are working or not working at all because they're not sure how it connects to the bottom line of the business (and they end up spending wayyyy too much $$ on ineffective tactics as a result).

if you're going to be advocating for extra resources down the line, you have to have a good understanding of how your current efforts are impacting the business and why the ones that are succeeding are succeeding. being able to speak at a CMO level + show that you know what you're talking about is way more important in the long run than really becoming an SME in any particular area of marketing (imo anyway). this will also help you develop a more robust marketing strategy (for content and beyond) since you'll have a better idea of which types of content will actually perform as opposed to trying out a variety of tactics and seeing what sticks — since you're a team of one, hopefully this can also help narrow your focus until you get to grow your team too :wink:

in terms of actually setting an actionable goal around this, I think it depends on the way your business is set up. it seems like you have a good level of access to your CEO, so I'd recommend asking them how where they think you can have an opportunity to make more of a strategic impact and connecting more with the other leaders across the business (in product, sales, etc) to see what kind of metrics they're tracking and obsessing over and gaining a better understanding around those things as well.

I hope this helps!

if you're going to be advocating for extra resources down the line, you have to have a good understanding of how your current efforts are impacting the business and why the ones that are succeeding are succeeding. being able to speak at a CMO level + show that you know what you're talking about is way more important in the long run than really becoming an SME in any particular area of marketing (imo anyway). this will also help you develop a more robust marketing strategy (for content and beyond) since you'll have a better idea of which types of content will actually perform as opposed to trying out a variety of tactics and seeing what sticks — since you're a team of one, hopefully this can also help narrow your focus until you get to grow your team too

in terms of actually setting an actionable goal around this, I think it depends on the way your business is set up. it seems like you have a good level of access to your CEO, so I'd recommend asking them how where they think you can have an opportunity to make more of a strategic impact and connecting more with the other leaders across the business (in product, sales, etc) to see what kind of metrics they're tracking and obsessing over and gaining a better understanding around those things as well.

I hope this helps!

text:
I’ve been in this situation myself as a sole marketer at a startup for over a year and a half.

Happy to answer more detailed questions in DMs, but in general, while getting to do a bit of “everything” is great for some time (you get to hone your general marketing skills, understand what you like/don’t like, acquire other soft sills, etc.) if you really want to grow in your _content_ career - you need to focus just on that.

Doing a bit of everything is not a great career accelerator as you don’t really have the time to define and execute a proper content strategy, and as a result, you don’t have strategic impact.

From your message I get the sense that you want to focus just on content, so my suggestion is to share that with your CEO and ask him if there’s any plans to hire a proper marketing director, so you can move into a content marketing role.

Content requires focus and investment and if you’re asked to split your time between that and a lot of other marketing and non-marketing initiatives (been there!) you won’t be able to have the impact you want with content and grow in your content career.

text:
Wanting to pass along your knowledge and help new CMs get a taste is AWESOME and fairly common. Humans are wired to teach/share knowledge :slightly_smiling_face:  This probably doesn’t directly relate to your current employer, so I suggest structuring your goals as “for my employer, specifically” and “investing in myself as a marketer.” You can share your personal career goals w/ them if you feel inclined, but it’s not necessary!

For your employer specifically, I recommend structuring goals around marketing outcomes, the metrics that indicate success for the business: leads, prospects, signups… depending on whether product-led or sales-led. Examples could be:
• Generate 2x as many leads as last year
• Grow lead generation 2x quarter over quarter
 I also think <@ULJBEFSJJ>’s recommendation to talk openly with your CEO / marketing leader is CRITICAL :slightly_smiling_face:  not only will this show your head is in the right place, it will also create more alignment, trust, and openness between you two, AND lead to the best possible goals. Truly an awesome recommendation, don’t ignore this.

Finally, for your _personal_ career goals, I recommend following your curiosity and *experimenting with side projects*. Getting curious to learn more about TikTok ads? Pitch a the founder of a startup you like on running some for them, and why it would make sense! (Or, just do it on your own dime if you’re willing & able.) This type of initiative-taking leads to rapid learning and, often, awesome new work opportunities :slightly_smiling_face:

Ultimately you will start to get clarity on the specific areas of marketing that you want to hone in on, like <@UP6K3LYQ7> said. It’s counterintuitive, but important to niche down, in order to become sought-out for what _you_ do best.

text:
I am so utterly lost, so if someone has some advice for me- I'd be very grateful.
I've been freelancing for 3 years now, and have gained 2 long-term clients in the past 6 months. Super happy to work with them, but of course, I want to work with more people, get better at what I do and raise my prices. 
Does anyone here have a strategy for gaining clients? I'm sure a lot of you do, and I'm really looking for some advice. I've researched a bunch of ways, but they've all been from blogs, I'd to hear from some real people for change.
So far, I've gotten one client from LinkedIn and one from Problogger. My website is underway, the idea is to host my portfolio there- but what is the goal usually with an online portfolio? Is it something you send a prospective client directly or something you optimize to show up on Google.
I have a ton of other questions too, but I think I'll stick to these two for now.
PS: This community is unbelievable.:heart:
